text:
Hey everyone! I have a pondering about job titles. :nerd_face:

*What are your thoughts on the importance of determining accurate job titles (esp. when you’re ready to go to your next job)? Am I totally overthinking it?* :eyes: 

Context:
> Officially, my title is ‘Head of Brand Communications’ at my current job. This was a change made from the previous folks in this position title of ‘Head of Content.’ I work on a small HQ team of 10 people _(edit: the other 9 run other non-content ‘departments’)_, but we manage an organization the size of 60+ countries and 1,500+ volunteers. That is, I do a lot as a Team of One. 
> 
> I do _everything_ from writing blog articles, publishing newsletters, social media — to writing PR-esque statements on behalf of the organization — to consulting/architecting multi-season content campaigns with clients. I’m afraid my current title does not actually capture the stronger content aspects of my job, but ‘Head of Content’ feels so watered down and unclear.

elements.text: Hey everyone! I have a pondering about job titles.
What are your thoughts on the importance of determining accurate job titles (esp. when you’re ready to go to your next job)? Am I totally overthinking it?
Context:

Officially, my title is ‘Head of Brand Communications’ at my current job. This was a change made from the previous folks in this position title of ‘Head of Content.’ I work on a small HQ team of 10 people
(edit: the other 9 run other non-content ‘departments’)

, but we manage an organization the size of 60+ countries and 1,500+ volunteers. That is, I do a lot as a Team of One. 

I do
everything

from writing blog articles, publishing newsletters, social media — to writing PR-esque statements on behalf of the organization — to consulting/architecting multi-season content campaigns with clients. I’m afraid my current title does not actually capture the stronger content aspects of my job, but ‘Head of Content’ feels so watered down and unclear.

text: hi! I was Content and Brand Manager and was just promoted to Director of Brand and Content. I think it's about what you see as more strategic to your next role after this.

elements.text: hi! I was Content and Brand Manager and was just promoted to Director of Brand and Content. I think it's about what you see as more strategic to your next role after this.

text: In sort of a weird/philosophical meta-consideration here, I'd say think of a job title as a kind of very focused content, and ask who the reader persona is.  For instance, if it's someone in the C-suite that wants to "place" you in the organization, they'll probably ignore narrative descriptions like "head of" and look for keywords like "manager," "director," or "VP," in order to quickly place you on the various org charts you've occupied.  Line managers and peers might be more interested in the narrative descriptors and qualifiers like "senior" and such.

elements.text: In sort of a weird/philosophical meta-consideration here, I'd say think of a job title as a kind of very focused content, and ask who the reader persona is.  For instance, if it's someone in the C-suite that wants to "place" you in the organization, they'll probably ignore narrative descriptions like "head of" and look for keywords like "manager," "director," or "VP," in order to quickly place you on the various org charts you've occupied.  Line managers and peers might be more interested in the narrative descriptors and qualifiers like "senior" and such.

text: FWIW, if those 60 people are "under" you as far as the organization is concerned, I'd say you have a strong case for a Director+ title, whether they're contractors/volunteers or not.  That's a big organization to run

text:
While you are more than a title, I do think the right title can provide more context and help define who you are to others.

I was the Communications and Grants Coordinator for several years. When the department director (my boss) was let go, they didn't fill the role. (And I didn't want it! ha)

I then asked our CEO if I could change my title to Communications and Grants Director. My narrative was that it was a more senior title, I already 'owned' the responsibilities, and it would help solidify who I was in the community if I had the Director title.

He said "sounds good to me!" :grinning:

text: We've recently implemented Google Optimize on our website and are doing a/b testing of content pages. Has anyone run any good tests that saw results? Interested in any ways to boost engagement, so tests that improve time on page, newsletter subscriptions, # of pages viewed, demo request

text: Hey Theresa – we run split tests frequently – to do everything from testing copy & design changes on key pages like pricing pages/the homepage of our clients’ sites all the way to testing actual new pricing tiers. What in particular were you looking for? Coming up with the actual potential “changes” to test? :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hey Theresa – we run split tests frequently – to do everything from testing copy & design changes on key pages like pricing pages/the homepage of our clients’ sites all the way to testing actual new pricing tiers. What in particular were you looking for? Coming up with the actual potential “changes” to test?

text: Yes! Interested in content pages specifically and changes you've tested. One we saw huge success with was adding gifs to some of our download pages to show what was behind the form, rather than telling through words. Looking for more creative ideas to drive more content engagement!

elements.text: Yes! Interested in content pages specifically and changes you've tested. One we saw huge success with was adding gifs to some of our download pages to show what was behind the form, rather than telling through words. Looking for more creative ideas to drive more content engagement!

text:
Wow, thanks for all your comments!

<@UUJBMNRNF> That is so true. I hadn’t thought about job titles for awhile because I didn’t want to tie myself mentally to it, but as I start to think about future moves, I realized there were some nuances that might matter. Thanks so much for your response!

elements.text: Wow, thanks for all your comments!

That is so true. I hadn’t thought about job titles for awhile because I didn’t want to tie myself mentally to it, but as I start to think about future moves, I realized there were some nuances that might matter. Thanks so much for your response!

text: <@UUH2ESL66> It ain’t an easy life :smile:

elements.text: It ain’t an easy life

text:
Ah nice! Usually with those types of changes, we don’t run A/B tests to validate our subjective ideas on what’s a better experience for subscribing/downloading, etc. because they aren’t that “mission-critical” in most cases (though all design decisions are definitely backed up by best practices/logic). That being said, the general question of what you can do to drive more engagement with content is a really interesting conversation – interested to hear what others have to say.

The main one that comes to mind because it always has the biggest impact is the overall branding/design of the site – the results of it not only being done really well but also suitable to the people we have in mind somehow never fails to impress us. More comments, more shares, more links, more sign-ups, more conversions. More of everything good basically :)

text:
Nothing to add really, except I totally feel you. I’m a “Director of Content,” team of two. But I do everything from reading my boss’ Medium posts before publishing, up to making Lots of Content happen each month for a couple Fortune 200 companies.

Our company is only 15 people. My bosses are nudging me into _more_ responsibility. They want me to come with up processes and high-level visions for clients while other people do the busy work of writing content briefs, managing writers, editing copy, etc. The hands-on editorial stuff is what I love and miss.
